title: Peter Costello leads Mitch Fifield send-off
text:
Profound mediocrity has its rewards. Former communications minister Mitch Fifield will take his ease on New York’s East River in a fortnight, having resigned from the Senate on August 16 and his replacement, former Corangamite MP Sarah Henderson, awaiting only the Victorian Parliament’s ratification of her preselection to take his place on the red leather. Profound mediocrity has…

Having plotted against prime minister Tony Abbott in 2015 and vaulting into Cabinet, Fifield then doublecrossed Malcolm Turnbull last August, lining up behind Peter Dutton. Little wonder Scott Morrison induced him outta there. The man’s estrangement from loyalty aside, 15 years as a complete ministerial passenger secured his absence from the Liberal pantheon.

On Friday, Fifield gathered those who still remember him for lunch at Melbourne institution, Bamboo House. It was also a chance for Future Fund and Nine chairman Peter Costello to gaze upon his protégés: with Fifield, Speaker Tony Smith, state opposition leader Michael O’Brien and GRACosway managing director Richard King, all alumni of the Treasurer’s office. A motley legacy – like with Costello’s 11 budgets, a couple didn’t quite sing. Former Liberal state director (and now Asahi executive) Julian Sheezel rounded out the table.

Fifield’s residence on Beekman Place adjoins that of Australia’s Consul General, Alastair Walton, whose term expires in July. A Goldman Sachs vulgarian appointed senselessly by Turnbull, ScoMo is no fan. Tick tock…

These people. And in New York! It bears contemplation by any prime minister’s confidant (or irritant): imagine where you might get sent if you were half good.
description: On Friday, Fifield gathered those who still remember him for lunch at Melbourne institution, Bamboo House.
